did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives, Cornell University Library

bioghist.head: ORGANIZATIONAL HISTORY
bioghist.p: The majority of the members and officers of the Telecommunications International Union were women. At one time the union represented more than l00,000 telephone workers in the U.S. and Canada. At a special convention held in February l986 delegates voted to dissolve the TIU. Vice- President Joan Noonan remarked "we have earned a very distinguished place in the history of the labor movement... and we can hold our heads high and be proud."

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Access to the collections in the Kheel Center is restricted. Please contact a reference archivist for access to these materials.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use:
userestrict.p: This collection must be used in keeping with the Kheel Center Information Sheet and Procedures for Document Use.

Federal court rulings on TIU status; re. Imogene Amirault court case to exclude eleven of the thirteen TIU member unions from participating in a special convention to affiliate with AFL-CIO; Shaughnessy's protest of his re-election defeat as President of Connecticut Union of Telephone Workers.

scopecontent.p: Ballots on affiliation sent to members, January 30, 1985; CWA, IBEW, and Connecticut Union of Telephone Workers' propaganda against TIU affiliating with AFSCME; correspondence between Shaughnessy and George Sherwood, President, and George Carlson, Vice President, Connecticut Union of Telephone Workers; re. affiliation vote defeated and plans to "regroup and strengthen the TIU" underway; re. disaffiliation of CUTW and UTW; AFL-CIO rejection of TIU application for affiliation; Shaughnessy becomes "full-time" President of TIU; 14-page "TIU Eighth Annual Convention Summary" (ff.29); CWA and IBEW continue to create roadblocks for TIU affiliation with any other AFL-CIO unions; announcement of need for serious organizing campaign due to membership decline; upcoming 1986 bargaining issues; locals holding back per capita dues owed to TIU; other TIU locals vote to disaffiliate; 4-page letter to members from Shaughnessy discussing the difficulties: "I have given it my best shot... cannot in good conscience recommend either of these two unions [IBEW and CWA] to the TIU membership," announces his resignation as President, August 14, 1985 (ff.34); Jesus Orosco elected President effective September 1, 1985 (ff.34); TIU office closes effective September 30, 1985; TIU dissolves effective March 31, 1986, 11:59 pm.
